intro: Amblyanthera hispida, commonly known as the hairy amblyanthera, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, and it produces small, pale yellow flowers. It is typically found in tropical and subtropical regions, often in moist, shaded environments. Amblyanthera hispida is not widely cultivated but is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and potential ecological roles.
